Lerner's interpretation is that as a result of the Fall, "humanity, in this act of acquiring a higher level of 'knowing,' assumes the burden of distinguishing between good and evil and of choosing the good in order to be saved"; but so far as humanity's newly-won knowledge is, in part, sexual knowledge, the burden falls more heavily on the woman, because God forbids her the "free and open sexuality of the fertility-goddess," symbolized, at the time Genesis was written, by the serpent (The Creation of Patriarchy [New York: Oxford UP, 1986] 196-97).

Lerner herself defines patriarchy as "the manifestation and institutionali- zation of male dominance over women and children in the family and the extension of male dominance over women in society in general" (239).

Kearney thus summarizes Kant's "Copernican Revolution": "Being would henceforth be conceived not as the transcendent origin of meaning, but as a representation of the human subject—or, more precisely, as a production of the human imagination.
